key_points: 13 US service members were killed in a terrorist attack at Kabul airport, Afghanistan.
The attack also left at least 15 other US service members wounded, later updated to 18.
Pentagon press secretary John Kirby and CENTCOM spokesman Capt. Bill Urban confirmed the casualties.
This marks the first US military combat deaths in Afghanistan since February 2020.
At least 95 Afghans were also killed and an additional 120 to 140 were injured.
The attack was claimed by the Islamic State, according to Gen. Kenneth McKenzie, head of US Central Command.
US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin expressed deep condolences and emphasized the mission's continuation.
President Joe Biden highlighted the ongoing threat from ISIS-K to US and allied forces, as well as to civilians.
Criticism has been levied against the Biden administration for its handling of the withdrawal from Afghanistan.
Secretary Austin pledged support for the families of fallen service members and affirmed the mission's importance.
spokespersons: Gen. Kenneth McKenzie (Head of US Central Command)
